posts.cooked:
Hopefully im not missing something…but what relative encoder are you trying to use exactly??

The through-bore gives you the absolute position, but doesn’t count rotations so you can’t just use that

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked: How do you have the encoder wired to the Spark MAX?

We’re using this through bore encoder ( Through Bore Encoder - REV Robotics ) and in the description it says it is both incremental and absolute, we took that to mean it can record relative values too. Is that incorrect?

Its similar to this picture, except we used an alternate encoder adapter to to connect the sparkmax and the encoder.

image 1218×803 67.2 KB

image 1218×803 67.2 KB

image 1218×803 67.2 KB

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked:
Are you using the alternate encoder adapter ( Alternate Encoder Adapter - 2 Pack - REV Robotics ) Or the absolute encoder adapter ( Absolute Encoder Adapter - REV Robotics )

Relative mode will use the alternate encoder adapter, absolute mode will use the absolute encoder adapter. Theres no built in way to read both at the same time with a single adapter.

link_counts.title: Alternate Encoder Adapter - 2 Pack - REV Robotics

posts.cooked: We’re using the alternate encoder adapter ( Alternate Encoder Adapter - 2 Pack - REV Robotics ) , so it should be in relative mode. The relative encoder values stays a zero when we test it though. So I’m not sure what went wrong.

link_counts.title: Alternate Encoder Adapter - 2 Pack - REV Robotics

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked:
There’s a different type of encoder for the Alternate Encoder.

declaration: package: com.revrobotics.spark, class: SparkMax
So if I use getAlternateEncoder() in the code, then the relative encoder values will be displayed? I’ll try that and let you know if it works. Thanks!

Still having the same issue- I’m using the absolute encoder adapter with the bore through encoder but there are no relative encoder readings showing- only the absolute encoder readings. What’s the best way to measured encoder readings if it continues to reset- store the readings as a variable and add one?

posts.name: Travis Hoffman
posts.cooked:
desperatecoder101:

Still having the same issue- I’m using the absolute encoder adapter with the bore through encoder

Whether “absolute” or “alternate” - I think you need to ditch both adapters if you’re trying to get a REV throughbore encoder to return relative/incremental values.

You’re using a CIM , right? For relative/incremental mode , the picture you linked above is actually how you SHOULD connect a Throughbore Encoder to a Spark MAX running a brushed motor like a CIM :

image 820×750 52.6 KB

image 820×750 52.6 KB

image 820×750 52.6 KB

Linked from - Using Encoders with the SPARK MAX | REV ION Brushless

If that’s the case, I imagine you should be able to use getEncoder to read the encoder the same as you would to read the encoder on a brushless NEO with its encoder cable plugged into the Encoder port:

declaration: package: com.revrobotics.spark, class: SparkBase

As for absolute mode - you already know how to hook that up and get data it seems - via the Absolute Encoder Adapter.

I know you want the absolute angle to accumulate beyond a single 360-degree rotation.  I’ve always wanted the encoder to do that myself.  But when connecting it to a SparkMAX through the Absolute Encoder Adapter, I’ve only ever observed the same behavior you have - it resets to zero when it rolls over.

Now one thing I SWEAR I saw working way back when they first introduced the Throughbore encoder - bypassing the SparkMAX entirely and hooking it DIRECTLY to the RoboRIO’s digital IO via one of the included cables in the bag permitted absolute angles to accumulate beyond 0 and 360.  That could just be a figment of my imagination - someone (preferably from REV) is going to have to check me on that one.

link_counts.title: Using Encoders with the SPARK MAX | REV ION Brushless
